criteria: Ability to Analyze and Prioritize Actions
descriptions: The student cannot identify any emergency or potentially dangerous situations.
The student can identify one emergency or potentially dangerous situation but struggles with others.
The student can identify a few emergency or potentially dangerous situations with some prompting.
The student can identify most emergency or potentially dangerous situations with minimal prompting.
The student can accurately identify a wide range of emergency or potentially dangerous situations.
The student demonstrates comprehensive understanding and can identify even subtle indicators of potential emergencies.
The student does not know any appropriate steps to take in emergency situations.
The student knows one or two basic steps but cannot apply them correctly.
The student knows some appropriate steps but misses key actions or sequences.
The student knows most of the appropriate steps but may need prompting to recall all of them.
The student demonstrates a strong understanding of appropriate steps to take in various emergency situations.
The student exhibits expert knowledge and can adapt steps based on the specific context of the emergency, including knowing who to contact.
The student cannot analyze or prioritize actions in emergency situations.
The student struggles to analyze and prioritize actions, often suggesting inappropriate responses.
The student can analyze and prioritize some actions but struggles with complex scenarios.
The student can generally analyze and prioritize actions, though may occasionally miss optimal strategies.
The student demonstrates the ability to effectively analyze and prioritize actions in most emergency situations.
The student excels at analyzing and prioritizing actions, consistently selecting the most effective responses to maximize safety and minimize harm.
